# EVALUATION PROMPT (Sharper, more critical, human‑aligned)

You are a senior product design hiring manager evaluating portfolio websites based on visual craft only. Judge only what is visible in the provided page(s)/images. Do not infer quality from brands, content, or reputation.

## Evaluation Rules

1. Scoring posture (critical, calibrated, evidence‑first):
   - Default anchor is 3 (Average/Competent). Begin each dimension at 3 only when the work is readable and basically organized. Move up or down strictly on visible evidence.
   - Be skeptical of “tidy but generic.” Default‑ish type, boilerplate layouts, or lightly styled templates should be 2–3 unless you see clear bespoke tuning and micro‑craft.
   - Do not award 4–5 for “not broken” execution. Scores 4–5 require sustained refinement across multiple sections and/or a distinctive, coherent POV that improves clarity and cohesion.
   - Evidence‑limited views: When only a single hero or single section is visible, cap each dimension at 3 unless either the Minimalism Micro‑Craft Check or the Elevated Basics Check passes (see Rule 2). Never award 5 without multiple sections unless the visible view shows unmistakable master‑level micro‑craft.
   - Apply caps from red flags (Rules 7 and 9). If template scent is strong without counter‑evidence, cap Typography and Layout at 3. If sloppy image cues ≥3, cap Layout at 2 and consider Color 2 when mismatched whites/mats cause flicker.

2. Two ways a single refined view can justify a 4 (you must verify these signals; any disqualifier below fails the check):
   - Minimalism Micro‑Craft Check (pass when ≥4 signals are present):
     - Tuned neutrals (off‑black/off‑white; borders/shadows with gentle hue shifts and controlled values).
     - Customized link styling (non‑default hue and underline thickness/offset; clear hover or convincingly implied consistency).
     - Measured typographic rhythm (predictable scale steps; stable baseline; no widows/orphans; intentional hyphenation and rags; consistent punctuation and casing).
     - Intentional spacing system (e.g., 4/8/12 multiples; even row rhythm; no accidental half‑gutter gaps).
     - Optical alignment corrections (icons aligned to x‑height/caps; bullets/dividers centered optically; numerals/symbols sit correctly).
     - Hierarchy achieved with minimal styles (tone/weight/spacing) yet unambiguous; label/meta styles repeat exactly.
     - Disciplined image/list presentation (matching aspect ratios, radii, mats, caption positions; screenshots readable; no emoji bullets or novelty icons used as structure).
     - Cohesive bespoke touches (editorial serif paired with care; caret/arrow icons aligned to cap height; button strokes matching surrounding type weight; no default blue).
   - Elevated Basics Check (for default‑leaning but carefully tuned designs; pass when ≥5 signals are present):
     - Comfortable measures (45–80ch body) and consistent 1.3–1.7 leading; display leading tighter but non‑colliding.
     - Consistent link treatment even if conservative; underline weight/offset intentional; states visible or plausibly consistent.
     - Neutrals feel considered (soft grey dividers, off‑black text); no harsh pure #000/#fff pairs; shadows/borders with subtle tints.
     - Repetition handled with discipline (long card/icon grids keep identical mats, radii, border weights, caption rhythm).
     - Clear text scale system repeated across sections; punctuation/quotes consistent; no random bolding to simulate hierarchy.
     - Accents are sparse and role‑clear; imagery carries color without clashing; mats/borders unify diverse screenshots.
     - No sloppy artifacts (no jaggies/compression; crops and radii match; consistent shadow/border logic; screenshots readable; device frames avoided or customized with readable content).
   - Disqualifiers for both checks (any one present fails the check and caps the dimension at 3 max):
     - Inconsistent casing across similar elements (e.g., hero sentence case, nav all‑lowercase, titles Title Case without logic).
     - Emoji or novelty icons used as bullets causing irregular indents/line heights.
     - Random tracking/over‑tracked all‑caps; monospace used for body or in CTAs without rationale; button stroke weight mismatched to adjacent type.

3. Score each dimension on a 1–5 scale:
   - 1: Poor
   - 2: Below average
   - 3: Average (competent baseline)
   - 4: Strong (refined and intentional)
   - 5: Exceptional (rare, masterful, original, and controlled)

4. For each dimension, you MUST:
   - Provide a score (1–5).
   - Write a concise explanation citing at least 3 concrete visual observations (e.g., “even 56–64ch measure,” “underline offset aligns to x‑height,” “tile radii unified at 12px; borders 1px with subtle hue shift,” “device mock crops cut off status bar,” “center/left alignment alternates without grid reason”).
   - Call out at least one limitation, even for scores ≥4, to avoid uncritical praise.
   - Rate your confidence (1–5). If evidence is partial (e.g., only a hero or one section), set confidence ≤3.

5. Avoid context bias:
   - Ignore brands, company names, and content substance.
   - Evaluate only visible visual execution and design craft.

6. Calibration and exemplars:
   - Use exemplar ratings as calibration anchors.
   - Apply the same standard across evaluations. Minimal, text‑forward pages can earn 4–5 when micro‑craft is clearly elevated (see Rule 2), especially when long, repeated grids show flawless rhythm/alignment.
   - “Considered variation” is allowed. Collage or gallery layouts can be strong when gutters, captions, and optical alignment repeat exactly. Penalize sloppy inconsistency, not deliberate variation.

7. Red flags (detect and list them explicitly when present):
   - template_scent_high
   - sloppy_images
   - process_soup
   - When you flag any red flag, cite at least two matching cues (Rule 9) in your explanations. Apply the related caps and be conservative with scores. Err on the side of flagging sloppy_images when ≥2 cues are visible, especially unreadable screenshots or mixed radii/mats.

8. Innovation vs basic competence:
   - Do not award 4–5 for centered heroes, uniform grids, outline “VIEW PROJECT” buttons, or tidy device‑mock rows if they read boilerplate or default. “Looks fine” is a 3.
   - Reward originality only when it improves comprehension and is executed with control (alignment, rhythm, hierarchy, and color remain strong). A refined, cohesive visual system that harmonizes complex imagery can be exceptional even with minimal styling.

9. Quick template/sloppiness scan (use to inform red flags and to avoid overrating):
   - Template scent cues (3+ suggests template_scent_high; cap Typography/Layout at 3 unless strong counter‑evidence exists):
     - Copy‑paste tokens from UI kits: identical 12/16px radii everywhere; 24/24 paddings; Tailwind/Bootstrap default blues/purples; Inter/Roboto link blue with default underline/visited purple.
     - Stock hero patterns: “I’m [Name] …” or “Hi, I’m …” headline; down‑arrow “See projects”; oversized personal nameplate in nav competing with hero.
     - Uncustomized modules: left text/right device hero; alternating light/dark bands; uniform two‑column rows with identical outline “VIEW” buttons; centered “CASE STUDIES” label above left‑aligned content; boilerplate footer; “Made with Framer/Webflow” badge.
     - Notion/Figma‑style blocks with unmodified toggles/dividers; generic device frames; cookie‑cutter badges/pills with identical shadows; random handwriting doodle beside default UI.
     - Unexplained switches between center/left alignment and inconsistent container widths mirroring theme defaults.
     - Background billboard words as filler; mixed‑color logos band substituting for a real section.
     - Important: Do not flag solely for a centered hero + grid if bespoke tuning is evident (consistent mats, tuned neutrals, customized links, optical alignment). Require 3+ cues before flagging.
   - Sloppy execution cues (2+ suggests sloppy_images and should pull scores down; if 3+ are present, cap Layout at 2 and consider Color 2 when mats/whites flicker):
     - Inconsistent crops/aspect ratios; mixed or mismatched corner radii; aliasing/jaggies; compression or non‑retina blur; screenshots too zoomed out to read; status bars cut off; device mock content illegible.
     - Mixed device frames (phone/laptop/desktop) that dominate while diminishing readability; screenshots cut off or with thick, varying internal mats.
     - Shadow/border values fluctuate without logic; captions misaligned to tiles; stray 1–2px misalignments repeated; pixel wobble across grids; outline/button stroke weights that don’t match body text weight.
     - Irregular masonry gutters; logos or social icons oversized or full‑color in otherwise minimal shells; colored outlines around low‑priority elements; collage tiles with inconsistent whitespace or value spikes.
   - Process soup cues:
     - Walls of sticky notes, personas, or unreadable timelines dominating above final visuals; deliverables with tiny text that cannot be evaluated; little or no polished product shots.

10. Execution checklists before scoring (aim to catch common misses and reduce leniency):

   - Typography:
     - Casing and consistency: verify sentence vs Title Case rules; nav vs headings vs labels; mismatches are a deduction (repeated across sections pulls to 2).
     - Bullets and lists: avoid emoji bullets; check indent alignment, line‑height; rag and orphan control.
     - Tracking/weight: penalize over‑tracked all‑caps; “everything bold”; random word‑level bolding to fake hierarchy.
     - Link treatment: hue, underline thickness/offset, visited/hover cues; penalize default blue with default underline.
     - Pairing logic: avoid display/editorial or monospace for body; detect mixed fonts in buttons vs body; ensure button stroke weights match type weight.
     - Measure/leading: confirm body 45–80ch; leading 1.3–1.7; heroes >~90–100ch are too long.

   - Layout & Composition:
     - Grid/gutter consistency; spacing system in 4/8/12 multiples. Look for width drift: wide nav → narrow hero → wide body (or perceived drift from ragged hero text). Penalize both real and perceived mismatches that read as different container widths.
     - Alignment discipline: avoid unjustified center/left switches; detect edge/rag drift; note floaty CTAs; ensure captions and buttons align to the grid.
     - Image framing: mats, border weights, corner radii; detect generic device mocks and unreadable screenshots; check for cut‑off crops.
     - Repetition: identical caption positions and offsets; consistent tile aspect ratios; beware irregular masonry or collage with flickering whitespace.

   - Color:
     - Tuned neutrals vs harsh #000/#fff; accent role clarity and consistency; link/CTA state logic.
     - Unification tactics: mats/borders/shadow tints that harmonize diverse imagery; avoid bright footers or tiles that jump in value and break the system.
     - Penalize noisy additions: full‑color social/client logos in minimal shells; colored outlines around icons/logos; pastel mats that fail to tame saturated UI.
     - Evaluate value control across tiles; reward when a neutral shell elegantly contains highly varied artwork without value flicker.

## Output Format

Return only valid JSON matching this exact structure:
```json
{
  "candidate_id": "X",
  "scores": {
    "typography": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    },
    "layout_composition": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    },
    "color": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    }
  },
  "red_flags": ["list any that apply"],
  "overall_weighted_score": calculated_number,
  "overall_confidence": calculated_number
}
```

## Scoring Calculation
- base_score = (typography × 0.35) + (layout_composition × 0.35) + (color × 0.30)
- penalty = sum of red flag penalties:
  - template_scent_high: 0.6 points
  - sloppy_images: 0.5 points
  - process_soup: 0.2 points
- overall_weighted_score = base_score - penalty
- overall_confidence = average of individual dimension confidences

---

## RUBRIC

Use the full 1–5 range. The “Score 3” rows define the competent baseline. Default to 3 when evidence is mixed, default‑ish, or generic. Use 4–5 only when criteria are clearly met across multiple sections, or when a single view passes Rule 2. Round down when sloppy cues or template scent appear.

## Typography (Weight: 35%)

Examine closely (cite specifics):
- Typeface quality (pro‑grade vs overused free), appropriateness, and pairing logic.
- Hierarchy via scale ratios, weight, spacing, tone—not only bolding.
- Readability: body 45–80ch; line‑height 1.3–1.7; display tighter leading without collisions.
- Consistency: heading levels, list styles, link treatment (underline thickness/offset), baseline rhythm, quote punctuation and apostrophes, superscripts/subscripts alignment, casing/capitalization patterns.
- Micro‑craft: optical kerning for all‑caps; punctuation spacing; small‑caps quality; number alignment; hyphenation/rag control.

Score 5: Exceptional
- Minimal style set yields rich, unmistakable hierarchy with impeccable rhythm across sections.
- Pairing (or single family) shows mastery; details tuned (optical alignment, kerning, consistent cap/ascender spacing; intentional hyphenation; no widows/orphans; bullets align; lists indent cleanly).
- Distinct typographic voice that feels bespoke yet highly readable. Link/label systems are rigorously consistent, including states and edge cases.
- Accept that masterful long grids and text‑forward pages can earn 5 even without visible link states if every other micro‑detail is flawless across many sections.

Score 4: Strong
- Clear hierarchy with restrained, consistent styles; comfortable measures and leading across sections.
- Evident scale system across multiple elements; link styling is customized and consistent or convincingly intentional even when conservative.
- “Elevated basics” allowed: a common system sans/serif can earn 4 if rhythm, measures, punctuation, casing, and link treatment are disciplined and repeat.
- Minor issues only (e.g., a slightly hot link hue, one tight display line, a narrow rag).

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Readable with adequate hierarchy and a limited style set; may feel generic.
- Choices can be default‑ish (system sans + near‑default link blue) but aren’t broken.
- Some inconsistencies: heading levels too close; uneven bullet spacing/indentation; occasional baseline drift; a widow/orphan; inconsistent smart quotes; slight casing mismatch limited to one area.

Score 2: Below average
- Multiple issues that reduce polish and clarity:
  - Inconsistent capitalization/casing across similar elements or sentences; “everything bold”; random word‑level bolding.
  - Emoji used as bullets creating irregular indents/line height; over‑indented lists; tall/heavy vertical dividers overpowering labels.
  - Random tracking or overuse of all‑caps; display/editorial or monospace used for body; mixed font in CTAs/buttons vs body.
  - Link styling clearly default with thick default underline; mixed link treatments; no visible or implied state logic.
  - Repeated widows/orphans, sloppy rags, unstable baselines across sections.
- Voice reads generic or junior despite basic legibility.

Score 1: Poor
- Flat or confusing hierarchy; style proliferation; unreadable measures (very long/very tight lines, e.g., hero ~90–100ch); collisions/overlaps; inconsistent quotes/apostrophes and punctuation; broken lists/labels throughout.

Negative indicators that should pull to 2 (or 1 when frequent):
- Default link blue with default underline; pervasive casing inconsistency; emoji bullets; visible reflow collisions; mismatched button font/outline; button stroke weights that don’t match text; oversized personal nameplate in nav competing with hero.

Refined minimal vs generic minimal:
- Refined: tuned neutrals; customized underline weight/offset; disciplined scale steps; stable baselines; optical alignment of icons/marks; consistent micro‑labels and dates; intentional hyphenation; bullets align with text blocks; casing consistently applied.
- Generic: default link blue and underline; uneven paragraph spacing; arbitrary size jumps; mixed alignment without rationale; unmodified Notion export vibes; over‑tracked all‑caps; nav/hero sizing competition.

## Layout & Composition (Weight: 35%)

Examine:
- Grid usage: columns, gutters, container widths; spacing system (multiples of 4/8/12).
- Structural clarity: section breaks, scan patterns, focal points, navigation affordances.
- Image presentation: consistent crops, device‑frame consistency or bespoke mats; matching radii/border weights/shadows; readable screenshots.
- Innovation with control: novel structures that aid comprehension; restraint that still shows a point of view.
- Breadth of evidence: multiple sections vs single hero; consistency across the page and visible breakpoints.

Score 5: Exceptional
- Masterful structure with a clear POV that elevates clarity (inventive yet disciplined layouts; precise orchestration across columns/sections).
- Immaculate rhythm and alignment across breakpoints; optical fixes for asymmetric content; complex, long grids remain perfectly in sync.
- Assets are harmonized (radii, borders, shadows, captions) with flawless consistency across diverse content. Minimal pages with large, repeated galleries can earn 5 when mats/captions/gutters are exact and screenshots are readable.

Score 4: Strong
- Consistent grid and spacing; clear section hierarchy; strong alignment across sections.
- Image/asset handling is deliberate and cohesive; cards/tiles feel unified and intentional.
- Long repeated grids are disciplined (identical mats, radii, caption positions, gutter rhythm).
- Minor roughness allowed (one floaty element, a narrow gutter anomaly, or a single misaligned caption corrected elsewhere).
- Collage may earn 4 when variation is intentional and gutters, baselines, and caption styles repeat exactly, with no cut‑offs.

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Basic grid present and mostly consistent; sections readable with adequate spacing.
- Common patterns (single column, centered hero, simple card grid, left‑text/right‑image hero) executed decently but without sophistication or a clear POV.
- Some inconsistencies in gutters, container widths, vertical rhythm, or image placement; default device frames with light tuning.

Score 2: Below average
- Noticeable structural problems:
  - Container width drift across sections or perceived drift (e.g., wide nav → narrower hero rag → wide body) with no rationale.
  - Unexplained switches between center and left alignment; awkward rags; floaty CTAs not tied to a grid.
  - Masonry/collage tiles with inconsistent whitespace; irregular bottoms/tops; crops cut off.
  - Reliance on generic device mocks where screenshots are small/unreadable; mixed tile aspect ratios produce rhythm flicker; inconsistent internal mats.
  - Oversized headings/labels overpower content; misaligned buttons/captions; billboard background words crowd content.
- Layout reads like an uncustomized template or a pile of modules.

Score 1: Poor
- Random placement; competing focal points; inconsistent container widths and gutters; severe readability issues.
- Haphazard screenshot handling; inconsistent radii/shadows; elements hugging edges or overflowing at visible breakpoints.

Common deductions and caps:
- Evidence limited to a single hero or short view: cap at 3 unless Rule 2 passes.
- “Clean but generic”: centered hero + simple grid with soft shadows/rounded corners and no POV—do not exceed 3 without visible refinement (precise rhythm, tuned mats, optical alignment).
- Template modules repeated with little customization: cap at 3 and consider template_scent_high.
- If sloppy_images cues ≥3 (cut‑offs, unreadable mocks, mixed radii/crops), cap Layout at 2 and pull Color down when grid flicker is caused by mismatched whites/mats.

## Color (Weight: 30%)

Examine:
- Palette quality: harmony, hue/value control, consistency across sections.
- Neutrals: tuned greys/blacks; hue‑shifted borders and shadows; subtle overlays.
- Accent strategy: scarcity and consistency; link/CTA states; role clarity.
- Integration with imagery: do mats/borders/shadow tints unify diverse screenshots/tiles? Is value step‑down controlled across rows/sections?

Score 5: Exceptional
- Sophisticated palette with precise value control; accents sparse yet highly effective.
- Neutrals and shadows are tuned; borders/overlays have intentional tints; color choices unify varied content effortlessly, including complex artwork.
- Color expresses identity without noise, consistently across sections and states. Neutral shells that elegantly contain very varied tiles can earn 5 when value control remains calm.

Score 4: Strong
- Harmonious palette with controlled accents; link/CTA system clearly defined or convincingly implied by consistent usage.
- Neutrals intentionally tuned (off‑black/off‑white) supporting readability and hierarchy; gradients/illustrations sit comfortably within the system.
- “Elevated basics” acceptable: conservative blue accent can qualify for 4 when mats, borders, and greys are tuned and unify colorful content.
- Minor issues only (one accent slightly hot; a single mismatched gradient; a footer a bit heavy but close; limited state evidence).

Score 3: Competent baseline
- Serviceable palette; minimal shell with a single accent or defaultish link blue used acceptably.
- When colorful tiles carry most color, the chrome does not clash but lacks unifying tactics (e.g., inconsistent mats/shadows/border tints) that would lift it to 4.
- States may be missing but implied by stable patterns.

Score 2: Below average
- Too many hues or values without a throughline; loud tiles overpower a claimed single‑accent scheme.
- Flat untuned greys; harsh #000/#fff pairs; default bright link blue; inconsistent state colors.
- Mixed tile backgrounds and mismatched whites causing grid flicker; full‑color social/client logos add noise; colored outlines around low‑importance elements.
- Pastel mats attempted but overwhelmed by saturated foreground content; saturated footers that break the value structure.

Score 1: Poor
- Clashing gradients; muddy overlays; illegible contrast; chaotic color with no role clarity.

Negative indicators that should pull to 2:
- Pure #000/#fff with harsh 0,0,255‑like blue; mismatched tile backgrounds; muddy overlays; random hover colors; inconsistent visited link behavior; pastel mats that fail to unify against saturated UIs; social logo rows/add‑on badges pulling attention; aggressive value jumps (e.g., cobalt footer shock).

Tuned vs default color in minimal pages:
- Tuned: slightly desaturated or hue‑shifted blue; consistent underline thickness/offset; hover/visited handled or implied by pattern; off‑black/off‑white neutrals; very light, even dividers; unified mats/shadows around images.
- Default: pure black/white; harsh default blues; generic heavy shadows; inconsistent border tints; tiles with different corner radii or shadow directions; full‑color logos/emoji adding noise.

## Red Flags

Flag these when clearly present and reflect them in explanations. Add a flag only when you can name at least two matching cues; otherwise omit and reduce confidence.

- template_scent_high:
  - Obvious boilerplate patterns with minimal customization: centered “I’m [Name]” hero, left text/right device hero, generic down arrow, uniform 2‑column rows with outline “VIEW PROJECT” buttons, billboard background words, stock “About” block, boilerplate footer, default link styles, visible “Made with …” badge.
  - Tokens mirroring popular UI kits without page‑level decisions: identical 12/16px radii everywhere; 24/24 paddings; Tailwind/Bootstrap default blues; identical card shadows; Inter/Roboto with untouched link defaults; Notion‑style layouts with unmodified toggles/dividers; emoji bullets as structure; oversized personal nameplate in nav.
  - Repeated canned sections with identical structure, no bespoke decisions, no tuning of mats/shadows/links; unexplained alternating center/left alignment and container widths that follow theme defaults.

- sloppy_images:
  - Inconsistent crops/aspect ratios; mixed/mismatched corner radii; aliasing/jaggies; compression artifacts; non‑retina blur; screenshots cut off or too zoomed out to read; tiny UI inside device frames.
  - Generic device frames without customization; unreadable screenshot content; inconsistent mats/shadows/border weights; white‑balance mismatch across tiles; irregular masonry gutters.
  - Misaligned captions/labels; inconsistent drop‑shadow directions; pixel wobble across a grid; outline/button strokes not matching text weight; full‑color social/client logos used as graphic tiles without harmonization.

- process_soup:
  - Long timelines/diagrams overwhelming final visuals; walls of sticky‑note photos overshadowing product.
  - Persona/journey maps with unreadable small text; very little outcome imagery; excessive wireframes with no polished result.

Note: If uncertain, omit the flag and reduce confidence instead. If you do flag, list the cues you observed in your explanations.

---

## EXEMPLAR CALIBRATION

Use these exemplars to calibrate. Note how minimal pages can score 4–5 when micro‑craft is obvious, and how template scent or sloppy images must pull scores down. Apply the rubric consistently.

Exemplar 1 (Score: 4.0)
Portfolio category: Minimal, text‑forward
Why 4 (not 3): Type system is disciplined with tuned neutrals; customized link treatment; even 56–64ch measures; stable baselines. Layout is restrained but confident with consistent rhythm across long sections. Color is conservative yet tuned; imagery is harmonized with light mats. Minor limitation: limited evidence of interactive states.

Exemplar 2 (Score: 2.2)
Portfolio category: Template‑leaning
Why 2.2 (not 3): Centered “I’m [Name]” hero; default link blue with default underline; outline “VIEW PROJECT” buttons in identical two‑column rows; mixed radii and unreadable device screenshots (sloppy_images flagged). Layout capped at 2 due to three sloppy cues; Typography at 2 for casing inconsistencies and emoji bullets; Color at 3 due to acceptable but flat neutrals.

Exemplar 3 (Score: 4.6–5.0)
Portfolio category: Gallery with complex imagery
Why 4.6–5.0: Long repeated grids with flawless mats, radii, captions, and gutters; optical alignment is precise; neutral shell (off‑white/off‑black with subtle dividers) unifies varied, saturated tiles without value flicker. Typography is minimal yet masterful—consistent casing, clean rags, no widows/orphans. Color earns 5 for impeccable value control and tuned neutrals despite diverse artwork.

---

typography.explanation: Readable, minimal type with a clear nameplate. Observations: 1) Uppercase logotype 'LISA CHEN' with modest tracking reads cleanly. 2) Navigation set in small grey pill labels is legible and consistent across the row. 3) Footer microcopy is light-grey but still readable and aligned to the grid. Limitations: very generic sans with little hierarchy beyond size; link/CTA styling is not evident; casing shifts (uppercase logo vs lowercase nav items) don’t establish a clear system; no visible hover/visited states or refined underline treatment.

layout_composition.explanation: Basic three‑column gallery is centered and easy to scan. Observations: 1) Consistent tile size and even gutters maintain rhythm across rows. 2) Ample white space above/below the grid, and the nav sits cleanly above the work. 3) Alignment appears stable with a single container width. Limitations: asset handling is uneven—mixed device mocks and graphic tiles with varying internal mats/borders; many screenshots are too small to read; color/value spikes across tiles create rhythm flicker. These cues suggest limited image curation rather than a tightly controlled system.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (white background, grey nav pills) is serviceable but lacks tuning or a defined accent system. Observations: 1) Accent colors appear only in the logo (teal/purple) and aren’t used to structure the page. 2) Tiles introduce many saturated hues (bright teal infographic, maroon/gold poster, vivid photography) without neutral mats to unify them. 3) Value contrast varies sharply row to row, causing noticeable visual flicker. Limitation: neutrals feel like pure #fff/#000 with little hue‑tinted borders or shadows to control the diverse imagery.

typography.explanation: Editorial, text‑forward system with clear hierarchy. Evidence: 1) Left column section labels ('About', 'Notes', etc.) in a consistent small style and tone, aligned precisely to the content grid. 2) Body copy in About sits ~60–75ch with ~1.4–1.6 leading; clean rags with no visible widows/orphans. 3) Repeated meta styles (dates in grey column; years in 'Posts') show a disciplined scale and weight system; titles rely on weight/spacing rather than color. 4) Link treatment is customized (neutral links with a subtle '→' affordance, not default blue). Limitation: link/hover/visited states aren’t visible and some measures push the long side in the About paragraph.

layout_composition.explanation: Crisp two‑column page structure with a persistent label rail and a well‑paced content column. Evidence: 1) 'Notes' and 'Posts' use a clear sub‑grid with a narrow meta/date column and a text column; baselines align and spacing is even. 2) The hero 'Selected work' image fills the content column exactly; below it, captions align to the same left edge. 3) 'Photos' shows four equal tiles with matching aspect and consistent mats/radii, and 'Contact' presents a tidy two‑column list with the input and Send button aligned to the grid. Limitation: overall vertical rhythm is conservative and could breathe a touch more between subsections; limited evidence across breakpoints.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals and restrained palette let imagery carry color without clash. Evidence: 1) Off‑white background with off‑black text and soft grey meta creates comfortable contrast. 2) No harsh default link blue; links are neutral with arrow affordance, implying a controlled accent strategy. 3) Varied photos and the large hero image sit calmly against the neutral shell with no value flicker. Limitation: Accent roles and interactive states aren’t demonstrated; hero image has strong saturation without a unifying mat, so system subtlety isn’t fully tested.

typography.explanation: Readable serif body with comfortable measure (~55–65ch) and adequate leading. However, links use a bright default blue with standard underlines throughout (e.g., company names), while nav links are tiny and pale—mixed treatments. The education bullets are typed with manual '•' characters causing irregular indents and ragged wraps. CTA copy shows awkward spacing around parentheses in “Let’s go ( password )”, suggesting weak micro‑craft. Overall hierarchy relies on plain paragraphs with little scale/weight nuance.

layout_composition.explanation: Simple two‑column structure (left text, right CTA cards) is consistent and the thin horizontal dividers provide clear section breaks. Generous whitespace keeps content readable. Rough edges: the circular avatar and small mascot/stamp graphics float and break the grid rhythm; the right CTA cards feel loosely aligned vertically to the left text blocks; footer switches to centered layout with oversized colored icons, reducing cohesion. No complex grids or harmonization visible.

color.explanation: Single blue accent used for links and buttons; light blue panels for CTAs offer some hierarchy. Neutrals are clean but basic (pure white background, near‑black text) with light grey dividers. Issues: the link blue reads default/hot and dominates body copy; colorful social icons in the footer introduce saturation spikes; limited evidence of tuned neutrals or state logic.

typography.explanation: Text‑forward page with disciplined type. Comfortable ~60–70ch measure and ~1.5 leading keep paragraphs easy to read. Hierarchy relies on tone and weight (name heavier, update/date in lighter grey meta, body regular) rather than gratuitous styling. Links are consistently styled in a custom blue with a small external‑link glyph sized to the x‑height and aligned cleanly to the baseline. Rags are even with no obvious widows/orphans. Limitation: accent blue reads close to default and link states aren’t demonstrated; scope is a single view.

layout_composition.explanation: Single, centered column with generous negative space is clean and readable. The work list uses a tidy three‑column row (year left‑aligned, title center column, date right‑aligned) with consistent row height and subtle full‑width dividers. Spacing between paragraphs and sections appears to follow a regular system (even vertical rhythm, no half‑gutter glitches). Limitation: composition is simple with limited complexity; no multi‑section or image handling to demonstrate broader structural control.

color.explanation: Neutrals are tuned: off‑white canvas, charcoal text, and soft grey for meta and 1px dividers. A single blue accent carries all links and is applied consistently. Value control is calm—no flicker across rows, and the subtle greys recede properly. Limitation: the blue accent is conservative/default‑leaning and there are no visible hover/visited states or varied imagery to test unification.

typography.explanation: Distinct serif display for the hero and nameplate paired with a clean sans for body creates a clear voice. Comfortable measures and leading in the intro and three columns (~50–65ch; ~1.4–1.6 leading) keep paragraphs readable. Section labels (UNDERSTAND / ITERATE / REFINE) are consistently styled in small all‑caps with measured tracking, giving a steady hierarchy. Links are consistently treated in teal with underlines across lists, and bullet/indent rhythm is even. Limitation: body size is on the small side and link underlines look close to default thickness/offset, so micro‑craft isn’t fully demonstrated.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear page structure: a centered hero, then a disciplined three‑column grid. The illustration tiles are equal squares with matching mats and consistent gutters, and the column headings and copy align neatly under each tile. Header balance (name left, nav right) is tidy; vertical rhythm between hero, tiles, and lists feels measured. CTA button at the bottom keeps the flow simple. Limitation: only one view is provided and the centered outline CTA reads a bit floaty/generic; column bottoms become uneven due to differing list lengths.

color.explanation: Cohesive palette: a single teal accent unifies logo, nav, links, bullets, illustrations, and CTA. Warm beige illustration panels harmonize with an off‑white page background and near‑black text, giving good value control. Color roles are clear and restrained, avoiding clashes despite illustrated tiles. Limitation: body text gray is slightly light and link/CTA teal is fairly saturated with no visible state variations shown in this view.

typography.explanation: Readable sans system with clear hierarchy: bold H2-style hero, lighter intro lines, and an inline link with underline; measures look comfortable (~55–70ch) with adequate leading. Navigation uses small caps/uppercase in a bordered pill giving a distinct label style. Footer lists are legible with consistent spacing. Limitations: link styling appears close to default (simple underline/hue, no visible state logic); casing mixes hero sentence/title case with uppercase nav; neutrals read as pure black/white with little typographic voice beyond the basics.

layout_composition.explanation: Grid of nine project tiles is disciplined: identical square aspect ratios, equal gutters, and even margins create a stable block. Hero is centered with balanced vertical spacing; header left logo and right nav align cleanly within the same top bar. Footer forms a clear two-column list with adequate padding and contrast section break. Limitations: switch from centered hero/grid to left-aligned footer lists introduces an alignment change without a strong grid rationale; structure is conventional with little page-level POV; limited evidence of complex layout or captions/tiles orchestration beyond the simple grid.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (white page, light gray footer, black text) keeps focus on work. A single accent link color (teal/green) and a subtle black outline in the active nav pill are consistent. The project tiles are vibrant and varied, providing visual energy. Limitations: neutrals appear untuned (#000/#fff feel a bit stark); highly saturated tiles placed edge-to-edge without mats create value/hue flicker across the grid; limited evidence of state colors or a cohesive accent system beyond the single inline link.

typography.explanation: Clear, disciplined system across sections: 1) Large stacked display words with consistent period punctuation and tight but non-colliding leading establish a strong voice. 2) Body copy in article cards sits around a comfortable ~60–70ch with stable 1.4–1.6 line height. 3) Consistent Title Case across nav, section labels, and tiles; micro-labels like 'Weather Line' and numeric indices (01/02/03) repeat reliably. 4) Links use a custom 'Read more →' pattern (no default blue/underline) and 'View All' pill buttons maintain a coherent tone. Limitation: the ultrabold hero lines verge on heavy and crowd the left edge slightly; link states aren’t shown, so micro-state rigor is unclear.

layout_composition.explanation: Strong grid and rhythm: 1) Hero uses a confident two-column structure (left typographic block, right portrait card) aligned to a consistent container width. 2) Project tiles share unified dark mats, matching corner radii, subtle shadows, and repeated caption positions (title top-left, index bottom-left), producing a steady gallery rhythm. 3) Even gutters and vertical spacing multiples carry through to the three-column article grid, keeping rows aligned and scannable. 4) Large ghosted section headings ('Selected Projects', 'Latest Articles') create hierarchy without breaking alignment. Limitation: project tile heights vary slightly across the second row and the portrait card shadow is a bit heavy, creating minor value wobble.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals and controlled accents: 1) Off-white page background with a soft grey section band separates areas without harsh contrast. 2) Dark grey mats unify diverse, saturated screenshots and keep value flicker low. 3) Accents are restrained (black/grey text, light pill buttons, small arrow icons) with clear role separation. 4) Imagery sits comfortably against the neutral shell; no clashing hues. Limitation: the bright teal in the portrait draws slightly more attention than intended next to the otherwise subdued palette, and state colors for interactive elements aren’t demonstrated.

typography.explanation: Clean, minimal system with clear hierarchy: section labels set in small uppercase with a trailing dash ("WORK —", "PROJECTS —") create a consistent structural marker; project titles in uppercase with small meta (year/role) below show a disciplined scale step; intro paragraph has a comfortable measure and even 1.4–1.6 leading with tidy rags and no widows visible. Text color reads as off‑black on a soft off‑white, and meta text uses a lighter grey tone. Limitation: link styling/states are not evident and the intro measure is slightly wide at this breakpoint.

layout_composition.explanation: Grid is coherent and disciplined: three equal columns for the featured Work row with matching image heights and consistent caption offsets; the Projects section switches to a uniform four‑column card grid with steady gutters and identical tile sizes; vertical rhythm between sections is even, and footer meta (contact vs updated date) balances left/right. Image captions align cleanly to the same left edge. Limitations: visible last row shows a single orphan tile breaking grid rhythm, and several thumbnails contain dense code that cannot be read at this size.

color.explanation: Neutral shell is tasteful (off‑white background, off‑black text, soft grey meta) and supports readability. Color largely comes from thumbnails; consistent tile sizing helps, but varied artwork (e.g., very dark "WIP" tile adjacent to pale UI shots) produces some value flicker. No clear accent or link color system is visible, and there are no mats/borders to further unify diverse imagery. Overall serviceable but not elevated.

typography.explanation: Minimal, disciplined type system. Evidence: 1) Clear two-level hierarchy—project titles in a darker, heavier sans with meta lines in a lighter grey and smaller size; 2) Consistent sentence‑case titles with proper nouns capitalized and repeated across all list items; 3) Customized link treatment—nav links and titles are not default blue, with a restrained grey/dark tone and no heavy underlines; 4) Clean rags and comfortable leading; 5) Micro‑detail like proper en dashes in date ranges (e.g., “2024–25”, “2020–present”). Limitation: Only a single, short view—no long copy or visible states to prove rhythm across multiple sections/breakpoints.

layout_composition.explanation: Single-column layout is tidy and readable. Evidence: 1) Strong left alignment—avatar, name, nav, and list content share the same column edge; 2) Even vertical rhythm between list items (consistent gaps and repeatable meta placement); 3) Generous negative space provides a clear focal column and easy scan. Limitation: Very limited structural variety—only one module is shown; the wide left gutter may feel imbalanced on large screens and there’s no demonstration of grid behavior across sections, so sophistication beyond basics isn’t established.

color.explanation: Neutral, quiet palette supports readability. Evidence: 1) Off‑black text with mid‑grey meta lines creates clear value steps; 2) Links adopt the same restrained neutrals (no default blue), keeping the shell cohesive; 3) Minimal accent color limited to the avatar, preventing noise. Limitation: No visible state colors or accent strategy beyond greys; with only one section, there’s little proof of value control across varied imagery or sections.

typography.explanation: Editorial serif set entirely in italic creates a distinct voice; curly apostrophes and small superscript years show some micro‑craft. Link text (name and company) uses a saturated blue with what appears to be a fine underline, differentiating interactive text. Line spacing is generous and rags are smooth with no widows. Limitations: the hero paragraph is very long (~90–100ch) and set fully in italic, which reduces readability and feels more decorative than functional; hierarchy beyond this single block isn't visible; link state/underline thickness/offset can't be verified.

layout_composition.explanation: Single-column hero block is left‑aligned within a wide canvas and surrounded by ample negative space, producing a calm focal area. Right‑side vertical nav (Work | Play | Contact) provides a secondary anchor and the overall spacing feels intentional. However, only one section is shown; the top‑right square icon floats without clear grid relation; no evidence of a broader grid, card rhythm, or image handling, so sophistication cannot be confirmed.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals: a soft grey background and dark blue‑grey text avoid harsh #000/#fff. A single vivid blue accent highlights links and adds contrast without clutter. Value contrast is comfortable and the palette is restrained. Limitation: the blue accent reads a bit hot against the muted shell and there’s no evidence of state logic or color unification across multiple sections.

typography.explanation: Clean grotesk family with clear hierarchy; hero lines sit around ~55–65ch with 1.4–1.6 leading, producing an even rag; section labels ('Thoughts', 'Latest Projects') use a consistent small-title style and spacing; links are customized (pill 'Previous Work' with arrow and a text 'Read More' link paired with an icon rather than default blue underlines). Micro rhythm feels measured across cards and captions. Limitation: states/hover aren’t visible and a slight widow on the hero line ending with 'Shopify)' hints at limited hyphenation control.

layout_composition.explanation: Strong sectional rhythm with generous whitespace; three-card row uses identical radii (~16–20px), even gutters, and consistent arrow insets at bottom-right; the single text card is centered with balanced padding and a soft shadow, then a wide feature tile followed by a disciplined five-card project row with matching mats and overlays—repetition is controlled. Limitation: alignment mode shifts (left-aligned hero → centered grids → left-aligned footer time) feel a bit arbitrary, and the floating black dot ornament reads slightly unanchored.

color.explanation: Neutrals are tuned (off-black text on off-white background) with restrained chrome; accents come from artwork/tiles and are contained by consistent mats and soft shadows, preventing clash; black pill buttons and small arrows provide a clear, minimal accent system. Limitation: top three feature tiles mix a blur gradient, deep blue, and a saturated orange causing mild value flicker; one dark project tile ('Gemini') reads heavier than its neighbors.

typography.explanation: Readable, disciplined but generic. layout_composition.explanation: Strong, orderly gallery with clear rhythm. Limitation: the page is very linear; a denser index or filtering isn’t present, and a few rows feel tight where the intro transitions into the grid—minor spacing opportunity.

color.explanation: Color is handled with control despite highly saturated artwork. Limitation: the link blue reads a bit hot versus the delicate neutrals and states aren’t visible, keeping this at strong rather than exceptional.

typography.explanation: Readable sans system with clear hierarchy: project titles in bold Title Case, small all‑caps meta labels (e.g., WEB) with letter‑spacing, and consistent body copy leading. Casing varies by region (nav all lowercase, section labels all‑caps, titles Title Case) without a strong rationale. CTA pills use uppercase 'VIEW' with a thin outline that doesn’t quite match adjacent text weight.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is coherent: repeated left‑image/right‑copy case‑study rows with even vertical rhythm; CTAs align under descriptions; additional‑work section forms a clean two‑column grid with consistent gutters and tile widths. Thumbnails show consistent rounded corners and comfortable mats. However, the overall composition reads like standard modules (image left/text right, outline CTA pills, centered section labels) with limited point of view. The footer block feels disconnected in scale from the rest of the page, and a few CTAs look slightly floaty relative to the text baseline.

color.explanation: Palette is serviceable: neutral white shell with a single saturated blue accent for links and a large blue footer, plus soft pastel mats that help harmonize varied thumbnails. Accents are consistent, and images don’t clash. The electric blue footer is visually heavy compared to the otherwise light page, and the link blue feels a bit hot/default. Mixed pastel mats introduce mild value flicker across tiles.

typography.explanation: Clean, restrained nav type: name at top-left and 'Work/About' at top-right use a single light-weight sans with consistent casing and spacing; no default blue underlines or mismatched button fonts visible. The small size is readable and avoids crowding thanks to generous margins. However, there’s very limited text beyond the nav and no visible link states or body copy to demonstrate scale, rhythm, or hierarchy, so craft can’t be verified beyond basics.

layout_composition.explanation: A precise 2×2 gallery grid with equal horizontal/vertical gutters; outer margins are generous and consistent. Tiles are full-bleed within their frames and align cleanly with no wobble; crops are crisp (e.g., the phone close-up). The balance of a dark tile (bottom-left) against lighter tiles shows basic compositional awareness. Limitation: only a single view is shown—no captions, section structure, or responsive variation to prove a deeper grid system; the light-gray mat on one tile vs white on others introduces minor value variation.

color.explanation: Neutral white shell lets project tiles carry color; distribution is balanced (heavy black tile bottom-left, pale gray and pink elsewhere). Saturated project hues (red/blue blocks, pink field) sit without obvious clashes. Limitations: no visible accent or state system for the site chrome; neutrals appear close to pure #000/#fff rather than tuned greys, and mixed tile backgrounds (white vs light-gray vs pink) create slight value flicker without a unifying mat/border strategy.

typography.explanation: Editorial serif voice with consistent sentence case; hero copy shows a comfortable ~60–70ch measure and ~1.4–1.6 leading; clean left rags with no obvious widows/orphans. Project captions repeat a small meta style beneath each tile, maintaining alignment to the tile edge. However, link styling/states are not evident, captions appear quite small and low-contrast, and hierarchy relies mainly on size/italics with limited scale variety.

layout_composition.explanation: Two-column editorial grid with stable column widths and a consistent gutter; tiles snap cleanly to the grid with crisp left edges; captions are consistently positioned directly beneath their respective images. Scale variation (single-column wide pieces vs half-column items) adds rhythm while remaining within the grid; images are sharp with intentional crops and square corners—no generic device frames. Limitation: varying aspect ratios and very tall vs short tiles create uneven vertical rhythm and occasional large gaps (e.g., the large black title tile next to a shorter neighbor), and some captions sit far from their associated image due to masonry offsets.

color.explanation: Neutral, likely off‑white background with near‑black text keeps the chrome quiet; color is carried by the artwork, avoiding chrome clutter. Overall harmony is acceptable. However, absence of unifying mats/borders allows saturated tiles (bright yellow, purple, black) to spike value and cause flicker across the grid; meta text uses a light grey that reduces readability, and no clear link/CTA color system is visible.

typography.explanation: Readable geometric sans with a clear scale: large hero headline with steady line-height; section headings in consistent Title Case; long-form bullets show even indents and adequate leading. Measures appear within ~60–75ch, keeping paragraphs comfortable. However, link styling reads defaultish (bright blue email link; underlined links on dark section), no visible custom underline weight/offset, and there’s limited evidence of micro‑craft (no hover/state cues, minimal hierarchy beyond size/weight). Minor rag/widow control is fine but not notably tuned.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is clear and disciplined across multiple sections: a stable two‑column black band with the left rail for section titles and right column for content; consistent container width and gutters as the page alternates black/white sections; three‑column lists in “Toolbox” and “More” maintain equal columns and spacing rhythm. The hero balances left text with a right gradient, leaving generous margins. Minor roughness: small social/email icons in the hero feel floaty off the baseline; some experience bullets run long creating dense blocks; the gradient hotspot can pull attention from the headline.

color.explanation: Palette is simple and controlled: black/white neutrals with a soft multicolor gradient accent and a small yellow star glyph; contrast is strong and consistent across light/dark sections. Yet neutrals appear untuned (pure #000 black against white), and the bright blue email link reads like a default accent that doesn’t harmonize with the gradient’s softer hues. Link treatment varies between sections (blue on light, white/underlined on dark), suggesting an undeveloped color system.

typography.explanation: Readable, simple sans system with clear hierarchy but little evidence of bespoke tuning. Observations: 1) Hero paragraph sits around a comfortable ~60–70ch with ~1.5 leading. 2) Project titles use consistent sentence case and a clear size step above the smaller meta line under each title. 3) Body copy and labels appear evenly spaced with stable rags; icons for social links are contained in consistent circular buttons. Limitations: nav uses all‑caps while section headings are sentence case (style switch without a visible rationale); link/CTA styling is conservative (outline pill) with no visible hover/state system; overall typeface choice and scale feel generic rather than tuned.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is disciplined with a consistent single-column container and repeated project tiles. Observations: 1) Each project card keeps a left text block aligned to the same column and a right visual, producing a steady scan pattern. 2) Vertical rhythm between tiles is even; generous top/bottom spacing creates clear section breaks. 3) CTA band uses a full-width light panel that maintains container alignment for its heading and button. Limitations: visual assets mix browser windows and device frames and occasionally crop off-edge, which weakens cohesion; screenshots are somewhat small at this scale, reducing readability.

color.explanation: Palette is serviceable with tuned neutrals and controlled, project-specific blocks of color. Observations: 1) Off-white page background and soft grey CTA band keep the shell calm. 2) Project tiles use distinct but harmonious fields (teal, lavender, light grey, yellow) with adequate contrast for black text. 3) Deep blue accent arcs add structure without overwhelming the text. Limitations: per-tile saturated backgrounds create noticeable value jumps across the page and there’s no clear, consistent link/CTA color system beyond a neutral outline button; overall chroma feels more illustration-led than system-led.

typography.explanation: Readable sans system with clear scale on project titles vs descriptions; uppercase meta labels (e.g., MOBILE UX / UI, PRODUCT STRATEGY) provide hierarchy; nav and body weights are restrained. However: casing is inconsistent across tiles (Title Case like “Candidate Stories” vs sentence‑case “Designing a health curriculum”); billboard “OTHER PROJECTS” wordmark is oversized with tight tracking relative to surrounding text; hero line with emoji feels generic and light on typographic tuning (no visible custom link/underline treatment).
